Literature Review: Pericytes are specialized cells that surround the surface of capillaries in both the brain and heart, playing a crucial role in regulating local blood flow. Recent studies have utilized optogenetic tools and genetically encoded reporters to investigate the 3D structure, anatomical organization, and physiology of pericytes in detail. These studies have revealed novel functions of pericytes and morphological features such as tunneling nanotubes in brain and tunneling microtubes in heart (1, 2). The distinct spatiotemporal metabolic requirements of the brain and heart tissues necessitate different functions of pericytes in blood flow control (3, 4). For instance, pericytes in the brain are involved in neurovascular coupling, a process that regulates the exchange of nutrients and waste products between neurons and the bloodstream (5). In contrast, pericytes in the heart are thought to play a role in regulating cardiac function and maintaining vascular tone (6). The mechanisms underlying these functions are complex and involve the interaction of pericytes with vascular smooth muscle cells and capillary endothelial cells (7, 8). Recent studies have also highlighted the importance of ion channels, such as KATP and Kir2.1 channels, in regulating blood flow in response to changes in tissue metabolic state (9, 10). The concept of electro-metabolic signaling, which links tissue metabolic state with blood flow regulation by pericytes and vascular smooth muscle cells, offers a novel mechanistic framework for understanding these processes (11). This framework posits that capillary ion channels serve as primary sensors of tissue metabolic state, triggering downstream signaling pathways that regulate blood flow (12). The resolution of the electro-metabolic signaling pathway will require further investigation, particularly with respect to the specific roles of pericytes and vascular smooth muscle cells in this process. Additionally, the development of novel optogenetic tools and genetically encoded reporters will be essential for further elucidating the 3D structure and function of pericytes in the brain and heart (13, 14). Overall, the study of pericytes and their role in regulating blood flow in the brain and heart is an active area of research, with significant implications for our understanding of cardiovascular and neurological diseases (15, 16).
